channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Huge California wildfires seeded cirrus clouds half a world away
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03560-y

Smoke from record-breaking fires in 2020 travelled all the way to Cyprus, where it helped to trigger cloud formation.
item.dc:title: Huge California wildfires seeded cirrus clouds half a world away

item.title: This astronomy centre just achieved gender parity. Here’s how it happened
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03678-z

Education, female leadership and gender-balanced hiring policies were key.
item.dc:title: This astronomy centre just achieved gender parity. Here’s how it happened
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: ‘Treasure trove’ of new CRISPR systems holds promise for genome editing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03697-w

An algorithm that can analyse hundreds of millions of genetic sequences has identified DNA-cutting genes and enzymes that are extremely rare in nature.
item.dc:title: ‘Treasure trove’ of new CRISPR systems holds promise for genome editing
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Réunion’s search for energy self-sufficiency
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03693-0

Whether the French island succeeds in producing all of its electricity depends not only on technology, but also on social and political will.
item.dc:title: Réunion’s search for energy self-sufficiency
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: The most powerful cosmic ray since the Oh-My-God particle puzzles scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03677-0

Scientists spot a particle of intense energy, but explaining where it came from might require some new physics.
item.dc:title: The most powerful cosmic ray since the Oh-My-God particle puzzles scientists
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: What the OpenAI drama means for AI progress — and safety
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03700-4

A debacle at the company that built ChatGPT highlights concern that commercial forces are acting against the responsible development of artificial-intelligence systems.
item.dc:title: What the OpenAI drama means for AI progress — and safety
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: ‘Politicians don’t understand science’: advisers give evidence at UK COVID inquiry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03706-y

Patrick Vallance, Chris Witty and others reflect on advising the UK government during the ongoing investigation into the country’s pandemic response.
item.dc:title: ‘Politicians don’t understand science’: advisers give evidence at UK COVID inquiry
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Author Correction: Structure and electromechanical coupling of a voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> exchanger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06880-1

Author Correction: Structure and electromechanical coupling of a voltage-gated Na+/H+ exchanger
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Structure and electromechanical coupling of a voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> exchanger
item.dc:creator: Hyunku Yeo
Ved Mehta
Ashutosh Gulati
David Drew

item.title: Phages overcome bacterial immunity via diverse anti-defence proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06869-w

Phages overcome bacterial immunity via diverse anti-defence proteins

Structural basis of Gabija anti-phage defence and viral immune evasion

item.title: Publisher Correction: Stress granules plug and stabilize damaged endolysosomal membranes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06882-z

Publisher Correction: Stress granules plug and stabilize damaged endolysosomal membranes
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Stress granules plug and stabilize damaged endolysosomal membranes

item.title: Forty slaughtered horses mark site of ancient mass sacrifices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03581-7

Cattle and other animals were slaughtered for rituals during the fifth century bc in what is now Spain.
item.dc:title: Forty slaughtered horses mark site of ancient mass sacrifices

item.title: These brain cells could influence how fast you eat — and when you stop
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03679-y

Scientists found the cells in mice — and say they could lead to a better understanding of human appetite.
item.dc:title: These brain cells could influence how fast you eat — and when you stop
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: That itchy, scratchy feeling strikes when Staph bacteria get to work
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03561-x

An enzyme wielded by a common skin bacterium acts on nerve receptors that trigger intense itching.
item.dc:title: That itchy, scratchy feeling strikes when Staph bacteria get to work

item.title: Polio could be eradicated within 3 years — what happens then?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03682-3

How to ensure polio doesn’t return after eradication, and the space explosion that’s baffling scientists.
item.dc:title: Polio could be eradicated within 3 years — what happens then?
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: HIV-1 Env trimers asymmetrically engage CD4 receptors in membranes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06762-6

HIV-1 Env trimers bound to one, two and three CD4 molecules are observed at membrane–membrane interfaces between HIV-1 and CD4-decorated virus-like particles.
item.dc:title: HIV-1 Env trimers asymmetrically engage CD4 receptors in membranes
item.dc:creator: Wenwei Li
Zhuan Qin
Elizabeth Nand

Walther Mothes

item.title: Sequential appetite suppression by oral and visceral feedback to the brainstem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06758-2

Genetically distinct neural circuits in the caudal brainstem receive feedback from the mouth and gut to regulate feeding behaviour on short and long timescales.
item.dc:title: Sequential appetite suppression by oral and visceral feedback to the brainstem
item.dc:creator: Truong Ly

item.title: Structural insights into intron catalysis and dynamics during splicing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06746-6

Analysis of the group II intron ribonucleoprotein shows the molecular interactions involved in branchpoint adenosine recognition, lariat formation and exon ligation, providing clues to the evolutionary conservation of structural components and catalytic mechanisms in premessenger RNA splicing.
item.dc:title: Structural insights into intron catalysis and dynamics during splicing
item.dc:creator: Ling Xu
Tianshuo Liu
Kevin Chung
Anna Marie Pyle

item.title: Repeated Omicron exposures override ancestral SARS-CoV-2 immune imprinting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06753-7

Exposure to early variants of SARS-CoV-2 results in immune imprinting in mouse models and in humans, reducing neutralizing antibody titres against Omicron variants, which could be mitigated with multiple updated boosters.
item.dc:title: Repeated Omicron exposures override ancestral SARS-CoV-2 immune imprinting

item.title: Trans-vaccenic acid reprograms CD8+ T cells and anti-tumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06749-3

A screen of nutrient-derived compounds identified trans-vaccenic acid as a promoter of effector T cell function, and functional assays demonstrate that this occurs via inactivation of GPR43 on T cells.
item.dc:title: Trans-vaccenic acid reprograms CD8+ T cells and anti-tumour immunity

item.title: Porin-independent accumulation in Pseudomonas enables antibiotic discovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06760-8

We use a whole-cell accumulation assay to assess the ability of non-antibiotic, structurally diverse small molecules to accumulate in Pseudomonas aeruginosa, with potential application in developing drugs to target this pathogen.
item.dc:title: Porin-independent accumulation in Pseudomonas enables antibiotic discovery
item.dc:creator: Emily J. Geddes
Morgan K. Gugger
Alfredo Garcia
Martin Garcia Chavez
Myung Ryul Lee
Sarah J. Perlmutter
Christoph Bieniossek
Laura Guasch
Paul J. Hergenrother

item.title: Imaging quantum oscillations and millitesla pseudomagnetic fields in graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06763-5

Imaging of quantum oscillations in Bernal-stacked trilayer graphene with dual gates enables high-precision reconstruction of the highly tunable bands and reveals naturally occurring pseudomagnetic fields as low as 1 mT corresponding to graphene twisting by 1 millidegree.
item.dc:title: Imaging quantum oscillations and millitesla pseudomagnetic fields in graphene
item.dc:creator: Haibiao Zhou
Nadav Auerbach

Yaozhang Zhou

Binghai Yan
Eli Zeldov

item.title: Structural insights into cytokine cleavage by inflammatory caspase-4
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06751-9

The human lipopolysaccharide receptor caspase-4 captures its cytokine substrate pro-IL-18 via a mechanism that is distinct from known caspase–substrate interactions, leading to inflammasome-independent IL-18 release from macrophages.
item.dc:title: Structural insights into cytokine cleavage by inflammatory caspase-4
item.dc:creator: Pascal Devant
Ying Dong
Julian Mintseris
Weiyi Ma
Steven P. Gygi
Hao Wu
Jonathan C. Kagan

item.title: Recognition and maturation of IL-18 by caspase-4 noncanonical inflammasome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06742-w

Activated human caspase-4 directly and efficiently processes IL-18 in vitro and during bacterial infections, cleaving the same tetrapeptide site in pro-IL-18 as caspase-1.
item.dc:title: Recognition and maturation of IL-18 by caspase-4 noncanonical inflammasome
item.dc:creator: Xuyan Shi
Qichao Sun
Yanjie Hou
Huan Zeng
Yong Cao
Mengqiu Dong
Jingjin Ding
Feng Shao

item.title: Epithelial IFNγ signalling and compartmentalized antigen presentation orchestrate gut immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06721-1

IFNγ signalling in epithelial cells promotes antigen presentation that confers intra-epithelial T cells the ability to limit extracellular ATP and consequent NLRP3 inflammasome activation, controlling pathogenic transformation of CD4+ T cells that promotes colitis and colorectal cancer in mouse models.
item.dc:title: Epithelial IFNγ signalling and compartmentalized antigen presentation orchestrate gut immunity
item.dc:creator: Ankit Malik
Deepika Sharma
Raúl Aguirre-Gamboa
Shaina McGrath
Sarah Zabala
Christopher Weber
Bana Jabri

item.title: Intermediate conformations of CD4-bound HIV-1 Env heterotrimers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06639-8

Single-particle cryo-electron microscopy structures of HIV-1 envelope (Env) trimers bound to one or two CD4 receptors identify intermediate Env conformations that precede host–virus fusion and inform the design of therapeutics to prevent HIV-1 infection.
item.dc:title: Intermediate conformations of CD4-bound HIV-1 Env heterotrimers
item.dc:creator: Kim-Marie A. Dam
Chengcheng Fan
Zhi Yang
Pamela J. Bjorkman

item.title: Hopfion rings in a cubic chiral magnet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06658-5

Transmission electron microscopy is used to observe three-dimensional topological solitons known as hopfions that in a chiral magnet are found to form rings around skyrmion strings, and a nucleation protocol for these rings is provided.
item.dc:title: Hopfion rings in a cubic chiral magnet
item.dc:creator: Fengshan Zheng
Nikolai S. Kiselev
Filipp N. Rybakov
Luyan Yang
Wen Shi
Stefan Blügel
Rafal E. Dunin-Borkowski

item.title: Autoimmune amelogenesis imperfecta in patients with APS-1 and coeliac disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06776-0

A large fraction of patients with APS-1 and coeliac disease develop enamel dystrophy, characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against the enamel matrix, which are generated through the breakdown of either central (APS-1) or peripheral (coeliac) tolerance to a battery of ameloblast-sepecific proteins.
item.dc:title: Autoimmune amelogenesis imperfecta in patients with APS-1 and coeliac disease
item.dc:creator: Yael Gruper
Anette S. B. Wolff

item.title: Genetic continuity and change among the Indigenous peoples of California
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06771-5

Genome-wide analyses of ancient DNA from individuals from California and Mexico shed light on the spread of Mexican ancestry to California and how it correlates with linguistic flow.
item.dc:title: Genetic continuity and change among the Indigenous peoples of California

item.title: Aligning climate scenarios to emissions inventories shifts global benchmarks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06724-y

Aligning the IPCC-assessed mitigation pathways with the national greenhouse gas inventories shows that key global mitigation benchmarks become harder to achieve, requiring achieving earlier net-zero and lower cumulative emissions.
item.dc:title: Aligning climate scenarios to emissions inventories shifts global benchmarks
item.dc:creator: Matthew J. Gidden
Thomas Gasser
Giacomo Grassi
Nicklas Forsell
Iris Janssens
William F. Lamb

Zebedee Nicholls

Keywan Riahi

item.title: Methane throughout the atmosphere of the warm exoplanet WASP-80b
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06687-0

Transmission and emission spectra of the 825 K warm Jupiter WASP-80b taken with the NIRCam instrument of the JWST show strong evidence of CH4 at greater than 6σ significance
item.dc:title: Methane throughout the atmosphere of the warm exoplanet WASP-80b
item.dc:creator: Taylor J. Bell
Luis Welbanks

item.title: Climate loss-and-damage funding: how to get money to where it’s needed fast
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03605-2

Finance for coping with the harms of climate change must be disbursed swiftly and pragmatically. The world’s largest existing climate fund for supporting climate mitigation and adaptation provides lessons.
item.dc:title: Climate loss-and-damage funding: how to get money to where it’s needed fast
item.dc:creator: Laura Kuhl
Istiakh Ahmed
M. Feisal Rahman
Jamie Shinn
Johan Arango-Quiroga
Saleemul Huq

item.title: ‘Loss and damage’ — the most controversial words in climate finance today
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03615-0

Crucial talks on how richer countries should compensate poorer countries for the effects of climate-related extreme weather are stuck. The COP28 climate summit must make a breakthrough.
item.dc:title: ‘Loss and damage’ — the most controversial words in climate finance today

item.title: Emissions scenarios and targets aligned to meet climate goals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03504-6

A mismatch in how carbon emissions are reported could endanger nations’ best efforts to meet targets for curbing curb climate change. A method for translating between reporting conventions offers a path forward.
item.dc:title: Emissions scenarios and targets aligned to meet climate goals
item.dc:creator: Chris D. Jones
Alexander J. Askew

item.title: Climate loss-and-damage funding: a mechanism to make it work
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03578-2

Compensating for the devastating impacts of heatwaves, hurricanes and floods after they occur is too slow. With climate risks accelerating, the world must predict who needs funds and when.
item.dc:title: Climate loss-and-damage funding: a mechanism to make it work
item.dc:creator: Richard H. Clarke
Noah J. Wescombe
Saleemul Huq
Mizan Khan
Bert Kramer
Domenico Lombardi

item.title: Magnetic hopfion rings in new era for topology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03502-8

A curious topological structure known as a hopfion ring has been induced in a magnetic material. The first of its kind in 3D, the ring is a tantalizing prospect for several branches of computing development.
item.dc:title: Magnetic hopfion rings in new era for topology
item.dc:creator: Hanu Arava
Charudatta M. Phatak

item.title: Daily briefing: Deep-sea mining might harm wildlife
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03698-9

Mining of the ocean floor for minerals could harm deep-sea jellyfish by stressing them out with sediment. Plus, Iceland braces for volcanic eruption and seven charts on the challenge to keep global warming below 1.5 °C.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Deep-sea mining might harm wildlife
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: JWST ends game of hide and seek with methane
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03500-w

The space telescope has helped to determine the atmospheric composition of an exoplanet using the light spectrum of its host star. Spectral changes as the planet orbits the star reveal the long-sought presence of exoplanetary methane.
item.dc:title: JWST ends game of hide and seek with methane
item.dc:creator: Gloria Guilluy

item.title: ChatGPT generates fake data set to support scientific hypothesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03635-w

Researchers say that the model behind the chatbot fabricated a convincing bogus database, but a forensic examination shows it doesn’t pass for authentic.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT generates fake data set to support scientific hypothesis
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Cherenkov blue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03515-3

A taste of history.
item.dc:title: Cherenkov blue
item.dc:creator: Charlene Brusso

item.title: Ancient DNA uncovers past migrations in California
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03503-7

Genomic data from ancient humans who lived up to 7,400 years ago, sampled from across California and Mexico, unveil patterns of migration that could explain how some Indigenous languages spread in parts of North America.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA uncovers past migrations in California
item.dc:creator: Alan Izarraras-Gomez
Diego Ortega-Del Vecchyo

item.title: Genes are often uninformative for dating species’ origins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03487-4

The time frame of a species’ origins provides context for evolutionary questions. However, dates from fossils are often inconsistent with estimates from genetic data. Emerging evidence points to a new explanation for this discrepancy.
item.dc:title: Genes are often uninformative for dating species’ origins
item.dc:creator: Matt Pennell

item.title: People go the extra mile for food
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03617-y

GPS data reveal that people travel far from home to buy food in the United States, challenging ideas about how access to food relates to unhealthy eating habits.
item.dc:title: People go the extra mile for food
item.dc:creator: Abigail Klopper

item.title: From the archive: a juice extractor in an insect’s gut, and amateur radio telephony
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03501-9

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: a juice extractor in an insect’s gut, and amateur radio telephony

item.title: A guide to the Nature Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03572-8

A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
item.dc:title: A guide to the Nature Index

item.title: AI should focus on equity in pandemic preparedness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03608-z

AI should focus on equity in pandemic preparedness
item.dc:title: AI should focus on equity in pandemic preparedness
item.dc:creator: Yuan Shen
Linghua Yu

item.title: Expose limitations of SDGs rather than trying to save them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03606-1

Expose limitations of SDGs rather than trying to save them
item.dc:title: Expose limitations of SDGs rather than trying to save them
item.dc:creator: Abhik Chakraborty

item.title: Deep-sea mining threatens jellyfish, suggests first-of-its-kind study
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03625-y

Sediment dislodged by ocean-floor mining could disrupt jellyfish metabolism, potentially causing the animals serious harm.
item.dc:title: Deep-sea mining threatens jellyfish, suggests first-of-its-kind study
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: China: personalized carbon accounting for consumers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03609-y

China: personalized carbon accounting for consumers
item.dc:title: China: personalized carbon accounting for consumers
item.dc:creator: Li Zhang
Lan Tao
Dongjie Sun
Fangyi Yang

item.title: The community should also support Palestinian scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03607-0

The community should also support Palestinian scientists
item.dc:title: The community should also support Palestinian scientists
item.dc:creator: Rana Dajani

item.title: Science in cities benefits rural communities, too
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03571-9

Shouting about the far-flung impact of city-based research can help counter attempts at urban–rural division.
item.dc:title: Science in cities benefits rural communities, too
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker

item.title: Iceland braces for volcanic eruption: what scientists are watching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03631-0

Researchers are tracking every aspect of the geological unrest, which began last month.
item.dc:title: Iceland braces for volcanic eruption: what scientists are watching
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: City-based scientists get creative to tackle rural-research needs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02992-w

Californian projects show how community engagement can break down urban–rural barriers in the United States.
item.dc:title: City-based scientists get creative to tackle rural-research needs
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: Daily briefing: These bats mate more like birds than mammals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03636-9

Serotine bats are the first mammals found to reproduce through non-penetrative sex. Plus, a genetic link to cannabis addiction and SpaceX’s Starship touches space for the first time.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: These bats mate more like birds than mammals
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Bright satellites are disrupting astronomy research worldwide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03610-5

A team of amateur and professional astronomers has determined that a satellite one-third of the size of a tennis court is one of the brightest objects in the sky — with dire consequences for ground-based astronomy.
item.dc:title: Bright satellites are disrupting astronomy research worldwide
item.dc:creator: Samantha Lawler

item.title: Is it too late to keep global warming below 1.5 °C? The challenge in 7 charts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03601-6

Chances are rapidly disappearing to limit Earth’s temperature rise to the globally agreed mark, but researchers say there are some positive signs of progress.
item.dc:title: Is it too late to keep global warming below 1.5 °C? The challenge in 7 charts
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: Chatbot catcher spots fake chemistry papers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03689-w

A machine-learning algorithm can spot chemistry papers written by ChatGPT better than other chatbot-detectors can. Plus, the super-accurate weather-forecasting AI that can run from a desktop computer.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: Chatbot catcher spots fake chemistry papers
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Divide and conquer: exploiting entropy to grow nanoscale barrier materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03361-3

The full promise of materials structured at the nanoscale can be realized only if they can be manufactured more efficiently and at the sizes required for device integration. An innovative method takes advantage of thermodynamic and kinetic effects to control the growth of stacked 2D nanosheets that can be used for practical applications from the nanoscale to the macroscale.
item.dc:title: Divide and conquer: exploiting entropy to grow nanoscale barrier materials

item.title: How AI is expanding art history
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03604-3

From identifying disputed artworks to reconstructing lost masterpieces, artificial intelligence is enriching how we interpret our cultural heritage.
item.dc:title: How AI is expanding art history
item.dc:creator: David G. Stork

item.title: Bridging the rural–urban health-care divide through community research partnerships
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02993-9

Scientists are working with Indigenous communities in Alaska to improve many facets of rural health.
item.dc:title: Bridging the rural–urban health-care divide through community research partnerships
item.dc:creator: Lucas Trout
Margaret Smith
Linda Joule
Stuart Harris

item.title: The highly mutated SARS-CoV-2 variant BA.2.86 is still neutralized by antibodies in the blood
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03376-w

The spike protein of BA.2.86 — a subvariant of Omicron — has a large number of mutations, and binds to its receptor in host cells with high affinity. Despite these characteristics, BA.2.86 is no more resistant to antibodies from vaccinated individuals than are the dominant variants that are currently in circulation.
item.dc:title: The highly mutated SARS-CoV-2 variant BA.2.86 is still neutralized by antibodies in the blood

item.title: Are rooftop solar panels the answer to meeting China’s challenging climate targets?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02991-x

Research is central to the success of major photovoltaic programmes in ramping up clean energy and alleviating rural poverty.
item.dc:title: Are rooftop solar panels the answer to meeting China’s challenging climate targets?
item.dc:creator: Yvaine Ye

item.title: Only 0.5% of neuroscience studies look at women’s health. Here’s how to change that
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03614-1

A new initiative challenges the severe neglect of women’s brain health from puberty through to pregnancy and menopause.
item.dc:title: Only 0.5% of neuroscience studies look at women’s health. Here’s how to change that
item.dc:creator: Emily G. Jacobs

item.title: Wi-Fi for neurons: first map of wireless nerve signals unveiled in worms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03619-w

Studies find a densely connected network of neurons that communicate over long distances, rather than across synapses.
item.dc:title: Wi-Fi for neurons: first map of wireless nerve signals unveiled in worms
item.dc:creator: Claudia López Lloreda

item.title: Polio is on the brink of eradication. Here's how to keep it from coming back
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03602-5

The campaign to eradicate polio could succeed in the next few years. But that’s just the beginning of a new challenge — keeping it away.
item.dc:title: Polio is on the brink of eradication. Here's how to keep it from coming back
item.dc:creator: Aisling Irwin

item.title: Swathes of Earth are turning into desert — but the degradation can be stopped
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03621-2

The latest United Nations data paint a grim picture. But countries that are getting land-restoration measures right provide some cause for hope.
item.dc:title: Swathes of Earth are turning into desert — but the degradation can be stopped

item.title: Microbiologist who was harassed during COVID pandemic sues university
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03518-0

At the heart of a New Zealand court case is the extent to which talking to the public constitutes an academic’s duty to society.
item.dc:title: Microbiologist who was harassed during COVID pandemic sues university
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: These bats are the first mammals found to have non-penetrative mating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03565-7

A European bat has been captured on film engaging in what appears to be an unusual reproductive strategy.
item.dc:title: These bats are the first mammals found to have non-penetrative mating
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: SpaceX Starship launch ends in explosion — what’s next for the mega-rocket?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03624-z

The craft travelled into space for the first time, before it self-destructed for unknown reasons.
item.dc:title: SpaceX Starship launch ends in explosion — what’s next for the mega-rocket?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Massive genetic study finds genes linked to cannabis addiction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03629-8

Data from more than one million genomes offer fresh insights into excessive cannabis use and its relationship to other diseases.
item.dc:title: Massive genetic study finds genes linked to cannabis addiction
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: These falcons excel at problem-solving — and outdo some of the world’s smartest birds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03563-9

A bird of prey called the striated caracara can figure out puzzles that are a struggle for Goffin’s cockatoos, which are known for their intelligence.
item.dc:title: These falcons excel at problem-solving — and outdo some of the world’s smartest birds

item.title: Eavesdropping on plant chatter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03613-2

Amie Fornah Sankoh studies how viruses commandeer plant communication at the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center
item.dc:title: Eavesdropping on plant chatter
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: ‘Electrocaloric’ heat pump could transform air conditioning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03595-1

Heat pumps are ubiquitous in the form of air conditioners. Scientists just invented one that avoids harmful refrigerant gases.
item.dc:title: ‘Electrocaloric’ heat pump could transform air conditioning
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: How to recycle unrecyclable paper cups
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03562-w

Chemistry can transform disposable cups into industrially useful structures called cellulose nanocrystals.
item.dc:title: How to recycle unrecyclable paper cups

item.title: Daily briefing: Why these PhD scientists went into teaching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03633-y

Some academics seeking a stable and fulfilling career are swapping the laboratory for the classroom. Plus, CRISPR and e-ink investigate how cuttlefish camouflage and how bacteria might help purify rare-earth elements.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why these PhD scientists went into teaching
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham
